questions.text: What Greek letter is represented by the symbol "Î¼"?

The next 4 questions deal with a block being dragged horizontally on a surface. A block with a mass of 12.0 kg is dragged on a flat surface AT A CONSTANT VELOCITY with an applied force of 14.0 N in the direction it is moving. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and the ground is unknown. Determine the magnitude of the force of gravity on the block
What is the magnitude of net force acting on the block?

answerChoices.text: It is not possible to determine the net force from the information given.

questions.text: What is the magnitude of the force of friction on the block?

answerChoices.text: It is not possible to determine the force of friction from the information given.

questions.text: What is the coefficient of kinetic friction between this block and the surface?

The next four questions deal with a block being dragged on a surface. It mass is 4.50 kg. And someone is dragging it with a force of 16.0 N in the direction it is moving. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and the ground is 0.170. The block is NOT moving at a constant velocity. What is the magnitude of the normal force on the block?
What is the magnitude of the force of friction on the block?
What is the magnitude of the net force acting on the block?
What is the magnitude of the acceleration of the block?

The previous set of questions dealt with a block being dragged by a horizontal force on a surface. In each of these problems, the magnitudes of the force of gravity and the normal force on the block were equal. Why was this true?

answerChoices.text: The block is not accelerating in the vertical dimension, and normal force and gravity were the only two vertical forces.
Normal force and gravity are always equal.
Normal force and gravity are a Newton's Third Law Pair of equal and opposite reactions.
The statement is false: Normal force and gravity are not actually equal in these problems.
